Use case: Cancer is driven by failures in systems that control when a cell should divide, repair DNA, or self-destruct. Targets in cell cycle or DNA repair pathways can be inhibited to halt tumor growth or to make cancer cells more sensitive to other treatments. A practical way to review such a set is to map the terms to checkpoints like G1/S or to DNA repair pathways like homologous recombination.
Use Case References (APA concise):
Hanahan, D. (2022). Hallmarks of cancer: New dimensions. *Cancer Discovery, 12*(1), 31–46. https://aacrjournals.org/cancerdiscovery/article/12/1/31/678558/Hallmarks-of-Cancer-New-Dimensions
Sherr, C. J., Beach, D., & Shapiro, G. I. (2016). Targeting CDK4 and CDK6: From discovery to therapy. *Nature Reviews Cancer, 16*(6), 353–367. https://doi.org/10.1038/nrc.2016.50

GO Terms: RNA-directed RNA polymerase activity; DNA-templated transcription; host cell membrane
Use case: The immune system uses small proteins called cytokines to send messages between cells. Sometimes these messages become too strong and cause damage, as in autoimmune disease. Medicines can block a cytokine or its receptor to reduce symptoms and protect tissues. To evaluate a cytokine set, look at which cells produce the cytokine, the diseases where it is elevated, and whether blocking it has proven benefits in clinical studies.
Use Case References (APA concise):
O’Shea, J. J., & Kontzias, A. (2017). Cytokine-targeted therapies: Can we go beyond TNF? *Nature Reviews Drug Discovery, 16*(5), 309–310. https://doi.org/10.1038/nrd.2017.6
Dinarello, C. A. (2018). Overview of the IL-1 family in innate inflammation and acquired immunity. *Immunological Reviews, 281*(1), 8–27. https://doi.org/10.1111/imr.12615

GO Terms: protein kinase activity; protein phosphorylation; membrane
Use case: Kinases act like switches that pass messages inside cells. They control growth, division, and survival. If a kinase stays on when it should turn off, cells can grow too fast. This is common in some cancers. Medicines called kinase inhibitors are designed to fit into the kinase and stop its action. In practice, doctors use them to slow tumor growth and to reduce harmful signaling in certain inflammatory diseases. When evaluating a kinase set, users often look for: the pathway it belongs to, tissues where it is active, and known drugs that already target it.
Use Case References (APA concise):
Fabbro, D., Cowan-Jacob, S. W., & Moebitz, H. (2019). Ten things you should know about protein kinases and inhibitor selectivity. *Nature Reviews Drug Discovery, 18*(8), 556–575. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41573-019-0054-1
Manning, G., Whyte, D. B., Martinez, R., Hunter, T., & Sudarsanam, S. (2002). The protein kinase complement of the human genome. *Science, 298*(5600), 1912–1934. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1075762

Use case: Bacteria and viruses depend on specific proteins to enter cells, copy their genetic material, and spread. If a drug blocks one of these steps, the infection slows or stops. To evaluate such a set, look for terms tied to entry, replication enzymes, or immune evasion mechanisms.
Use Case References (APA concise): Laxminarayan, R., et al. (2013). Antibiotic resistance—the need for global solutions. The Lancet Infectious Diseases, 13(12), 1057–1098. https://doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(13)70318-9; De Clercq, E., & Li, G. (2016). Approved antiviral drugs over the past 50 years. Clinical Microbiology Reviews, 29(3), 695–747. https://doi.org/10.1128/CMR.00102-15

GO Terms: lipid biosynthetic process; antibiotic biosynthetic process; phosphopantetheine binding
Use case: Cells convert food into usable energy through mitochondrial and metabolic pathways. When these pathways are out of tune, energy supply fails and disease follows, such as diabetes or fatty-liver disease. Targets in these pathways can be adjusted to restore healthier energy use. Key checks include which pathway the terms map to, the organ where it matters most, and biomarker readouts like glucose or lipid levels.
Use Case References (APA concise): Pagliarini, D. J., & Rutter, J. (2013). Hallmarks of a new era in mitochondrial biochemistry. Genes & Development, 27(24), 2615–2627. https://doi.org/10.1101/gad.214643.113; Samuel, V. T., & Shulman, G. I. (2016). The pathogenesis of insulin resistance: Integrating signaling pathways and substrate flux. Nature Reviews Drug Discovery, 15(4), 299–316. https://doi.org/10.1038/nrd.2016.198
